I have.  But JUnit alone isn't quite enough (which is why there are 
extensions, right?). See http://abbot.sourceforge.net

I tried developing programmatic extensions to java.awt.Robot to use for 
tests, and using JFCUnit.  Both resulted in a real pain writing code, 
and something developers only used if I forced them and QA certainly 
couldn't use.

So I abstracted the layer of user actions to be invoked from a 
hand-editable XML script, which also supports assertions for testing 
purposes.  I still have to push the developers, but now QA is writing 
some of the tests.

The result is the abbot testing framework.  Each script encapsulate 
semantic user actions mixed with testing assertions to verify GUI 
state.  The scripts can be invoked from a JUnit Test case (one is 
provided) and the failures/errors will show up as in any other JUnit 
test.  There's also a script editor which provides recording capability 
(which is far easier and quicker than painstakingly programming "move 
here, click here, move here, click here, move here, click here".  Also, 
since it's a script, there is no extra compile step when building and 
debugging tests.
